Our models indicate that for some Agave species the overlapping area with L. nivalis completely disappears under future climate scenarios. Suitable areas for A. parryi and A. palmeri tend to retreat North, opposite to what the models show for L. nivalis, which tends to retreat South. Studies on the pollination biology of A. palmeri suggest bats are important pollinators for this agave species
44, 45 . Our models also suggest that the pattern of agave richness dramatically changes in future scenarios, and the areas with two or more Agave species overlapping are greatly reduced (Fig.Â 4). The fewer agave species present in one region reduces the period with available flowers. This might result in foraging stress for the endangered L. nivalis and force them to migrate to other areas earlier. L. nivalis is also dependent upon caves located along the mountain corridor where it migrates
31, 32 so its ability to move will be dependent upon the availability of suitable caves for roosting.
